ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The past tense in Hebrew and a large amount of other vocabulary and grammar.
I continued to learn a lot this semester about both the Hebrew language and Israeli culture. I also gained a new confidence with speaking Hebrew.
I learned about the Hebrew language, and Jeewish and Israeli culture, this semester, we spent a lot of time studying past tense verbs

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Small homework assignments every night to practice what was learned in class were helpful, as were small group discussion activities in class. There wasn't a strong focus on strict translation, but rather a focus on original production in the target language. The grading is a little easy, so it's hard to get clear feedback sometimes.
I enjoy the small class size and the way we review materials consistently while also learning new things.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! The Hebrew department is so much fun at Yale. All the professors are lovely and take such good care of their students. It's like a little family. If you have any interest in Hebrew you should join the department.
Yes, taking Hebrew has been one of the best academic decisions I have made so far at Yale.
